qas.question: What did the Taylor Report recommend at the the Hillsborough disaster in 1989?

answers.text: a recommendation that standing terraces should be abolished

qas.question: What was the result of their recommendation?

answers.text: as a result all stadiums in the Premier League are all-seater

qas.question: How many stadiums have been closed down since Premier League started?

answers.text: Nine stadiums that have seen Premier League football have now been demolished.

qas.question: What was the total seating capacity of stadiums in the Premier League in the 2010-11 season.

answers.text: The combined total capacity of the Premier League in the 2010–11 season is 770,477 with an average capacity of 38,523.

context: As of the 2015–16 season, Premier League football has been played in <a4_0><b9_0>53<b9_0/><a4_0/> stadiums since the formation of the Premier League in <b10_0>1992<b10_0/>. The Hillsborough disaster in <b11_0>1989<b11_0/> and the subsequent Taylor Report saw <a0_0>a recommendation that <a5_0>standing terraces<a5_0/> should be abolished<a0_0/>; <a1_0>as a result all stadiums in the Premier League are all-seater<a1_0/>. Since the formation of the <b12_0>Premier League<b12_0/>, football grounds in England have seen constant improvements to capacity and facilities, with some clubs moving to new-build stadiums. <a2_0><a6_0>Nine<a6_0/> stadiums that have seen Premier League football have now <b13_0>been demolished<b13_0/>.<a2_0/> The stadiums for the 2010–11 season show a large disparity in capacity: Old Trafford, the home of Manchester United has a capacity of 75,957 with Bloomfield Road, the home of Blackpool, having a capacity of <a7_0>16,220<a7_0/>. <a3_0>The combined total capacity of the Premier League in the 2010–11 season is <a8_0>770,477<a8_0/> with an average capacity of 38,523.
